title: 105_hr4559
content: The "Prescription Drug Patient Choice Act of 1998" is also known as the Equity in Provision of Prescription Drug Coverage Act. It amends the Public Health Service Act to ensure fairness in the provision of prescription drug coverage under group health plans. The Equity in Provision of Prescription Drug Coverage Act requires group health plans to offer coverage for drugs not provided by network providers without charging higher premiums. The Equity in Provision of Prescription Drug Coverage Act mandates that health insurance plans must cover drugs from non-network providers at reimbursement rates equal to those from participating pharmacies. Plans can still limit covered drugs and impose benefit restrictions or cost-sharing. The Equity in Provision of Prescription Drug Coverage Act allows restrictions on coverage as long as they align with subsection (a). Group health plans must comply with notice requirements under ERISA. Amendments include adding section 2706 to ERISA. The Equity in Provision of Prescription Drug Coverage Act (SEC. 713) ensures fairness in coverage. Group health plans must follow ERISA notice requirements. Plans can still limit covered drugs and impose benefit and cost-sharing restrictions. Amendments are made to the Equity in Provision of Prescription Drug Coverage Act by inserting new item after section 712. "Amendments to the Equity in Provision of Prescription Drug Coverage Act include a new section for individual health insurance, ensuring equity in prescription drug coverage." The provisions of section 2706 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements. Section 2762(b)(2) is amended. Application to Medicare Managed Care Plans is also addressed. The Social Security Act is amended to meet the requirements of the Public Health Service Act for individuals enrolled in the organization. Additionally, a new section is added to Title XIX of the Act for Medicaid Managed Care Plans. Additionally, there is a focus on equity in provision of prescription drug coverage. The Social Security Act is amended to require health insurance issuers to comply with the Public Health Service Act for individuals eligible for medical assistance under a State plan. Waivers of this requirement are prohibited under specific sections of the Act. Additionally, Medicare supplemental policies are subject to new regulations under Section 1882 of the Act. The Social Security Act now mandates health insurance issuers to adhere to the Public Health Service Act for individuals eligible for medical assistance under a State plan. Medicare supplemental policies must also comply with Section 1882 regulations. Additionally, Section 8902 of title 5, United States Code, is amended. Section 8902 of title 5, United States Code is amended to include new subsections regarding group health plans and their compliance with the Public Health Service Act. The amendments made by subsection (a) will apply to group health plans for plan years starting on or after January 1, 1998, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by subsections (b), (c), and (d) of the Act will apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market, contracts for contract periods, and Federal financial participation for State plan expenditures, respectively, starting on January 1, 1998. The amendments made by subsections (e) and (f) of the Act will apply to medicare supplemental policies, medicare select policies, and contracts starting on January 1, 1998. Section 104(1) of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 is amended for coordinated regulations.
